Expectation1: Attending children's school events and activities
Situation1: Children are about to finish school, and the mother should pick them up
Expectation2: Prepare sermons and deliver weekly messages during Shabbat services.
Situation2: It is time to begin brainstorming potential topics for a sermon several weeks from now.
Story: I glance at the clock—2:45 p.m. My children will be tumbling out of their classrooms in fifteen minutes, eyes searching for me at the school gate. I promised them I’d be there, just as I always am, to hear about their day and walk home together. But my desk is covered in notes and books, the beginnings of a sermon swirling in my mind. Shabbat is weeks away, but the congregation expects inspiration, wisdom, something meaningful. I can’t leave it to the last minute; I owe them my best. My phone buzzes with a reminder: “Pick up kids.” My heart tugs in two directions. I want to be the mother who never disappoints, who listens to every story and holds every hand. But I am also their rabbi, and my community looks to me for guidance and hope. I stare at my half-written notes, then at the clock again, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which path to take.
